topic.title: Data Compression
topic.shortdesc: Couchbase Server supports data compression, both in its communications with internal and external clients, and within the server itself.

section.title: Overview
section.p: The compression of data potentially allows a larger working-set to be maintained in RAM. It may also reduce consumption of network-bandwith. A slightly higher consumption of CPU resources may occur, due to the handling of compression and decompression.

Couchbase data-compression is provided by Snappy, which is an open-source, compression-decompression library, written in C++. Compression is optionally applied to individual buckets, either by the server or by its clients. Clients elect to participate in exchanges of compressed data by using the standard HELO network command.

section.title: Where Data Compression Can be Used
section.p: The following illustration annotates the Couchbase Server-locations where compression can be applied:
The annotations are explained in the table below.

row.entry: External network clients based on the Couchbase SDK elect to participate in exchanges of compressed data by using the HELO command with flags that confirm support of the Snappy Compression datatype. This allows the client to send compressed documents to receive them from the server. Such clients must perform their own decompression when necessary.
Couchbase Server may store documents in compressed form in memory, depending on its own internal policies.
Couchbase Server stores documents in compressed form on disk.

Within a cluster, Couchbase Server-nodes elect to participate in compressed-data replication by means of the standard procedure for opt-in used by external network clients, such as the SDK. Compressed-data replication is optional: if not used, compressed documents are decompressed prior to replication.

Within a cluster, services elect to participate in compressed-data replication by means of the standard procedure for opt-in used by external network clients, such as the SDK. Services must perform their own decompression when necessary.
External clients elect to participate in compressed-data replication by means of the standard procedure for opt-in used by the SDK, and must perform their own decompression when necessary.
XDCR elects to participate in compressed-data replication by means of the standard procedure for opt-in used by the SDK; and must perform their own decompression when necessary.

section.title: Data-Compression Modes
section.p: Couchbase Data-Compression is handled on a per-bucket basis. Each bucket is configured to support one of three modes. After a client has negotiated the ability to participate in exchanges of compressed data, by means of the HELO flag, the actual handling of data depends on the mode supported by the specified bucket. The modes are:
These are described in the following sections.

section.title: Data-Compression Mode: Off
section.p: The Off compression mode is sometimes referred to as Legacy, and provides the behavior of Couchbase Server 5.0 and pre-5.0. Therefore, on receipt of a compressed document, Couchbase Server decompresses the document for storing in memory; and recompresses it when storing on disk. When sending the document back to the client, Couchbase Server sends the document in uncompressed form.
This compression mode is useful where client-side compression is either considered too consumptive of CPU resources, or has been so fully implemented as to require no compression on the server.
This mode is assigned by default to buckets upgraded from a previous version of Couchbase Server.

section.title: Data-Compression Mode: Passive
section.p: On receipt of a compressed document, Couchbase Server stores it in compressed form both in memory and on disk. When sending the document back to the client, Couchbase Server sends the document in compressed form, if this is required by the client.

On receipt of an uncompressed document, Couchbase Server does not compress it for storage in memory. Such documents are compressed for storage on disk, and are sent back to clients in uncompressed form.
Replication within the cluster uses a compression-enabled DCP stream.
This mode is assigned by default to new buckets, in post-5.0 versions of Couchbase Server.

section.title: Data-Compression Mode: Active
section.p: Couchbase Server actively compresses documents for storage in memory and on disk, even if the documents are been received in a compressed format. Documents are decompressed before being sent back to clients that do not participate in exchanges of compressed data.

section.title: Enabling Data Compression
section.p: Couchbase Server allows compression to be enabled by means of the following.

ul.li: The Couchbase Web Console, which allows buckets to be configured and updated.
The Couchbase CLI, which allows buckets to be configured and updated.
The cbbackup, cbrestore, and associated tools, which allow compressed documents to be requested in the backup stream.
The Couchbase SDK, which can elect to send and receive compressed documents.
Cross Data-Center Replication (XDCR), which can be configured to use data-compression end-to-end.
